content: I'm really enjoying Overleaf (not having to deal with local LaTeX) and the Quiver app is awesome ( https://q.uiver.app ) :+1:
I'm a fan of quiver too, but I can't stand overleaf. Luckily it offers git support, so I can locally sync my collaborators work on overleaf via git. :smile:

:+1: Out of curiosity, what is your setup like if not Overleaf? Downloading, installing and configuring LaTeX locally didn't seem like a fun task to me :sweat_smile:

The integration with Github is definitely nice though :+1:
Texpad is a pretty nice app if you're on Mac. It's just an editor though so you'll still need to install TeX to your computer.
On Windows getting MikTeX to work is trivial; I basically just downloaded it and clicked "yes" a bunch of times.
I have had a decent experience with TeXShop on my Mac. Not with TeXWorks.
i’ve been using TinyTeX with a nice text editor (SublimeText, for me) for the past while now and it’s been a real game changer for me, i love it!

I do a lot of coding so I've always got VS Code open. I am happy with it as an editor and don't need another one, but Overleaf is actually pretty decent for editing online. I do appreciate how a local editor can be preferred, but I think Overleaf does a pretty decent job for what it is :+1: :blush:

I would be happy to find a good extension for VS Code with previewing locally if anyone is aware of a good one. I didn't have luck and gave up trying when I found Overleaf :blush:
I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

Eric Forgy said:

I would be happy to find a good extension for VS Code with previewing locally if anyone is aware of a good one. I didn't have luck and gave up trying when I found Overleaf :blush:

[Edit: Wow. I just noticed the VS Code extension LaTeX Workshop has over 1M downloads and a 5-star rating. I should try that.]

I use VS Code and this extension is very good as it has a lot of nice macros already, but VS Code lets you create your own snippets and I found those to be much more helpful. For previewing I use SumatraPDF as it is easily customizable and very light, but SyncTex (to let me know which part of the pdf corresponds to which part of the code when I click on it and vice versa) was not trivial to set up and is still a bit finicky. As an example here is what my screen looks like most of the time: image.png

(I also read on some issue on Github that someone might integrate Quiver to VS Code)

Joe Moeller said:

I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

3 reasons for me: there are no customizable macros, it is quite a bit slower than my local installation and I need to reload the page at least once every hour for weird connection issues.
+1 for LaTeX Workshop on VS Code

Joe Moeller said:

I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

I think my primary reason is that it doesn't have all the shortcuts/text editing features I'm used to on VS Code.
This make writing on it frustrating. Contrary to some other cases in which you could argue is just a matter of habit, in this case the experience is definitely inferior (to me) since advanced text editing features do improve my workflow. So I can accept to switch from VS Code to any other advanced text editor, since I know eventually I will get used to it, but I can't switch to something which hasn't the features I need.

Fabrizio Genovese said:

I'm a fan of quiver too, but I can't stand overleaf. Luckily it offers git support, so I can locally sync my collaborators work on overleaf via git. :)

Indeed, this is something I was super happy to discover when writing my master thesis :laughing:

Eric Forgy said:

:+1: Out of curiosity, what is your setup like if not Overleaf? Downloading, installing and configuring LaTeX locally didn't seem like a fun task to me :sweat_smile:

The integration with Github is definitely nice though :+1:

Installing LaTeX\LaTeXLATE​X on linux is trivial, on Fedora you can do something like sudo dnf install latex-scheme-full, and I'm sure you can do the same with apt on Debian-based systems

Joe Moeller said:

I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

When you do a lot of coding, you start getting very picky wrt the editor you use. There are a lot of shortcuts and stuff you set up that make your work easier. For people using Emacs or Vim (not me) the level of customization is so high that it becomes practically impossible to give up on your macros without feeling a deep sense of frustration.

This is similar to tiling window managers: As soon as you try them, get used to them and start defining your keyboard shortcuts getting back to a "normal" desktop environment become so frustrating that it's really difficult to describe how unnerving any single interaction with the new system becomes. It is exactly the same feeling I get in having to use overleaf editor. There are a lot of things that I don't like: Continuous compilation is the dumbest waste of computational power ever conceived, having to "live" in a browser tab makes me feel trapped and constrained in pointless ways, and overleaf macros feel like I'm using something akin to Microsoft Office, which says it all.

As a general point: Forcing someone that has been working with computers for ages to change their to-go editor is a bad, bad idea. If you ever come up with something overleaf-like make sure to provide git integrations as they do!
Quiver is amazing. If it weren't for Quiver, my last preprint would still be my current draft :)

Joe Moeller said:

I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

During my formative years (ie during my PhD) one of my main work locations was on trains commuting in and out of London, with a non-existent internet connection. Then after I became a postdoc my main location was cafes were I intentionally never sold my soul for the "free" wifi, in order to be unplugged from social media and get work done. So to this day I like my critical software to run without an internet connection

For anyone who's a mac user I strongly recommend MacTeX, it's "batteries included" (I essentially never have to install packages, and it anyway comes with a little gui package manager), it comes with TeXShop which is a great editor, and it's built on the TeXLive compiler which is conveniently the same one used by arXiv

More recently I learned that Overleaf has git integration, but back in 2013 when I was first exposed to ShareLaTeX (which has since been eaten by Overleaf) that either wasn't the case or I didn't know about it, and by now it's too late and I'm old (??) and stuck in my habits
Is there any advantage to using Overleaf via git, when you can just use git on its own?
I think the main reason to do so is if you're collaborating with people using Overleaf, but prefer not to use it yourself.

Joe Moeller said:

I've also never understood what people don't like about Overleaf.

I like having maximal control over my working environment. If you lose internet, or if they push an update, then your workflow is disrupted.
I sometimes happen to need to generate fragments of TeX files as part of the build process (rendering Agda code). I think it would be difficult to do without a full Unix-like environment.

I agree with all the negative appreciation for Overleaf here, and I will add one more: the git integration is certainly useful, but the commits are no longer semantically meaningful, so that you don't really have any useful diffs (most commits only change a couple of characters). This means you have to spend more time checking what it was exactly that your authors changed. Not using the git integration means that you have no idea at all what your coauthors changed so that you have to reread way more.

A thing I did like Overleaf for was when we had to write a 100 word motivation. We were on Zoom and just real time edited the text to make it snappy. That was certainly less painful than either doing this via time-separated commits or via some kind of screen sharing setup in order to work on it collaboratively in real-time.
In general I don't understand why people make web apps for stuff that could be a native application shakes fist at kids

I don't see that there would be any benefit to having Overleaf as a native application: the complaints people seem to have are also its strengths, e.g. it only works online because it has server-side compilation of LaTeX, which can be faster and less painful than local compilation. Moving to a native application might improve UX, but wouldn't fundamentally change any of the other design decisions.

Licensing and advertising, usually

I'm a fan of quiver too, but I can't stand overleaf. Luckily it offers git support, so I can locally sync my collaborators work on overleaf via git. :)

I would like to know what's so good about quiver, which costs 10 bucks to try.

But I'd like to side with Eric. I am very happy with Overleaf -- yes, I wish they had more in terms of editing support, but the convenience of not having to update packages and the templates (also available if you don't use their software) is wonderful!

Wow, I have two full TeXLive installations here - one of a recent release, for general use, and one of TeXLive 2016, for Arxiv - and I though that most people here would be doing something similar...

I didn't expect that Overleaf would be so weel-rated. I need to give it a try.
I'd be interested if any existing TikZit users have used Quiver and have an opinion of how they compare, since I think they basically do the same thing
@Tim Hosgood what's specific to/special about TinyTeX? I've got MacTeX/TeXLive just because it comes out of the box, but it's enormous.

so TinyTeX is, well, tiny in comparison, because it doesn’t include any of the documentation files (that most people don’t even know exist i think), and it also installs itself entirely in one folder, so if you ever want to move computers, you can just copy that folder, or if you want to delete TeX and get a new version, you just delete that folder
@Tim Hosgood does it have all the packages? It's not like I use super-obscure packages, but I like not having to go and download one when I want to use it.
i think you have the option to install it with all the packages, and if you miss any then it’s just tlmgr install PACKAGE_NAME and you’re done

I was picky with my editor back when I did lots of C++. I guess I just never got too into any macros with my latex stuff. So I ended up just mostly being relieved when I found ShareLatex (later absorbed by OverLeaf) that I didn't have to fiddle with anything at all anymore. Just go to the website and it works and everything is stored there. Very convenient.

Jules Hedges said:

I'd be interested if any existing TikZit users have used Quiver and have an opinion of how they compare, since I think they basically do the same thing

I've used both, but neither extensively. I perceive tikzit as being good for strings, and quiver as good for pasting diagrams. Do they both do both?
I don't think that Quiver does string diagrams, and I wouldn't use TikZit for commutative diagrams. I do not feel like they have the same use case, really
Right, ok. That's what I was thinking.
Thanks, I missed that part
For a few years I made my commutative diagrams in raw tikz and only learned about tikz-cd a couple of years ago, so I still consider that the height of convenience
I do prefer raw tikz to tikz-cd actually

A lot of times I have to do some fine positioning in my diagrams and what happens is the following:

  • I fiddle with tikz-cd for hours
  • I give up
  • I re-do everything in tikz, and then it works
FWIW, I prefer tikzcd. It actually prevents me from fiddling too much because the options are somewhat limited. This is a good thing, imo.

All in all, for me there is always a 50% probability that tikz-cd won't fullfill my needs, and that I'll have to re-do everything and waste three times more time. All things considered going with raw tikz often saves me time.

Joe Moeller said:

FWIW, I prefer tikzcd. It actually prevents me from fiddling too much because the options are somewhat limited. This is a good think, imo.

It isn't when, for instance, you have to align nodes that vary widely in content
Tikz-cd will try to figure out the spacing for you and the result is guaranteed to be horrible
Agreed. In those scenarios, I usually either re-think my diagram's shape, or the object names, or I give in and do raw tikz.

In those cases what really works best is to manually position the nodes, imho. This corner case I'm talking about is especially evident when you want to compare two diagrams with the same shape but different vertexes
In those cases, what really matters is that the two diagrams have the same shape to make the comparison clear. That's where tikz-cd usually fails :frown:
Tikz-cd has some nice options called row sep and column sep.
Even so, tikzcd doesn't allow object names from different columns overlap in longitude at all. If one object has a super long name, it could change the proportions a lot.
It does! There's also a nifty but little-known option called between origins that tells it to disregard the width of object names when calculating column widths.
Wow, I should try that. Thanks!
Use it like \begin{tikzcd}[column sep={2.2cm,between origins}].
I think I learned that from Peter Lumsdaine.
